Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Resolving centennial- to millennial-scale trends in glacier extent and lake sedimentation in the Brooks Range, Arctic Alaska
Award.AbstractNarration: The goal of this collaborative project to reconstruct late Quaternary climate and glacier change in Arctic Alaska, one of few regions in the Arctic where mountain glaciers have left physical records of their former extent, making it valuable for comparing the timing and extent of mountain glacier variability between the lower latitudes and the Arctic. Several features of the climate and glacier history of the Brooks Range contrast with those from the North Atlantic region (which is often taken to represent the entire Northern Hemisphere in records of climate change) and currently available evidence indicates that the history of the Brooks Range more closely resembles glacier records from the southern Hemisphere. The investigators propose to develop records of climate change from lake sediments and records of glacier fluctuations using proglacial lake sediments and beryllium-10 dating of glacial features to address questions centered around four intervals of pronounced global change: (1) Last Glacial Maximum: Did glaciers retreat and temperatures increase in Arctic Alaska during the global LGM, as has been simulated by climate models? (2) Deglaciation: To what extent did climate change in Arctic Alaska coincide with North Atlantic climate fluctuations during deglaciation? (3) Holocene Glaciation: What was the extent of glaciers during (a) the Holocene thermal maximum, and (b) Neoglaciation? (4) Little Ice Age: Was it wetter or drier in the Brooks Range? The research will take place in suitable valleys (floatplane accessible valley with extant glaciers) in the northÂ­central Brooks Range. The project has several educational components, including support four graduate students and several undergraduate students and visits to the community of Anaktuvuk Pass to deliver presentations on climate research and the Brooks Range. The proposed research aims to produce well-dated and quantitative records of glacier and climate variability in the northernmost glaciated region of the U.S. Documenting the past behavior of arctic glaciers when subject to extreme climate events during the late glacial period and warm intervals like the Holocene can provide valuable insight to help better predict responses to future change.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Arctic is anticipated to warm more than any other place on Earth in the next century due to global warming. The large and rapid changes will impact (and in many cases already are impacting) glaciers, water resources, and ecosystems in the Arctic. In order to make realistic projections about the future impacts of warming on different regions in the Arctic, we must first understand the Arctic climate system itself (that is, we must understand the different ways that heat and moisture can be transported around our planet by the ocean and atmosphere). Documenting and examining climate patterns of past time periods is essential in order to understand how the climate system can respond to different types of perturbations. Because our period of direct observations, for instance with thermometer measurements and rain gauges, is very brief (shorter than 100 years in most arctic regions), we must rely on information that is naturally recorded in geologic archives to extend our observations in to the more distant past, to times when the climate system may have responded to natural perturbations.

 

As part of this project, we have reconstructed the temperature history of the central Brooks Range or Alaska during the past 12,000 years. We have done this using alkenone paleothermometry, an approach by which one can reconstruct the temperature of a lake’s water through time by examining the molecular structures of lipids that were produced by lake algae and deposited in the bottom sediments through time. We used a second approach, as well, in which we measured the hydrogen isotopes of lipid molecules (leaf waxes) produced by plants growing near our study lakes through time (once again, these lipids are preserved in the sediments at the bottom of the lakes). The hydrogen isotopes of the ancient leaf waxes provide a snapshot of the hydrogen isotopes in the precipitation of the Brooks Range at different times in the past – and this in turn provides information about the local temperature history and the history of atmospheric circulation (for instance, where precipitation originated, and how far it traveled to get to the Brooks Range).

 

Using these approaches, we have determined that the warmest summers of the past 12,000 years in the Brooks Range occurred between 12,000 and 10,000 years ago, and that at that time lake water temperatures were approximately 3 to 4 °C warmer than they were during the 20th Century. We had anticipated that this would be the case, because fundamental changes in the Earth’s orbit around the sun have taken place in the past 12,000 years, and we know that the Arctic received a greater amount of direct summer solar radiation 12,000 years ago than it does today. However, we also expected the summer temperatures to gradually decline between 12,000 years ago and present. What we found instead is that summer lake water temperatures were very dynamic during the past 12,000 years. While there was a general cooling trend, likely due to the gradual changes in Earth’s orbit, there were also abrupt temperature changes, some lasting on the order of centuries, that probably record major changes in the climate system (that is, the circulation of the atmosphere and oceans, which determine how warmth is delivered to the Arctic from lower latitudes). These dynamic changes attest to the fact that the Arctic climate system can transition between different modes of operation, and we will use these data to study the different mechanisms by which this may have occurred. Understanding abrupt climate changes in the past will be of direct relevance for trying to anticipate abrupt changes that may occur in the future.
